reasoning: Centrality: The critique targets the paper's conditional claim that, absent de dicto optimization, most survival-conditioned futures fall far short of mostly-great. This is indeed a central claim, but the paper explicitly acknowledges that forces like convergence and compromise could guide society toward good outcomes—deferring that discussion to the next essay. The paper's main argument in THIS essay is specifically about whether the target is narrow (fragility/fussiness), not about whether society hits it. The critique conflates the 'is the target narrow?' question with 'will society hit the target?' question. The paper explicitly sets up the navigation/aiming question for the sequel. So the critique is only partially central—it challenges the framing condition ('no serious coordinated efforts') but the paper already flags that de re pressures are addressed elsewhere. Strength: The critique is quite weak for several reasons. (1) The paper explicitly conditions on 'no more serious optimisation pressure than today arising from people who are trying to promote the very best outcomes de dicto' and notes that convergence/compromise is the topic of the next essay. The critique essentially says 'but what about convergence forces?'—which is anticipated and deferred, not ignored. (2) The de re selection pressures mentioned (legitimacy competition, migration/exit) are plausible for producing welfare floors and anti-torture norms, but the paper's argument is about reaching MOSTLY-GREAT futures (50%+ of best feasible value), not about avoiding the worst outcomes. Compressing the lower tail is compatible with still falling far short of eutopia. The paper's Section 3 technical analysis shows that even futures with no obvious catastrophes can fall far short on most moral views. (3) The critique doesn't engage with the multiplicative model, the technical analysis of bounded vs unbounded views, or the specific mechanisms by which value is lost (population ethics, digital welfare, resource allocation, etc.)—all of which are the core substance. It merely gestures at institutional selection without showing these pressures would address the specific failure modes identified. Correctness: The factual claims are largely correct—de re selection pressures do exist, legitimacy competition is real, and these can produce moral guardrails. But the inference that these compress the lower tail enough to make 'mostly-great' substantially more common is unsupported and likely overstated given the paper's technical arguments. The claim that the paper treats no de dicto optimization as implying 'weak optimization' is somewhat of a strawman—the paper is more careful than that. Clarity: Reasonably clear, though the key mechanism (how exactly de re pressures would push outcomes past the 50% threshold rather than just above zero) is left vague. Dead weight: Minimal. Single issue: Focuses on one coherent point about de re optimization pressures.
title: "De re selection pressures can erect moral guardrails without de dicto optimization"
